body: @ijuma would you mind reviewing this?
Could you update the JIRA ticket title accordingly as well? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3870
LGTM

@SinghAsDev, I left some initial comments, I didn't do a detailed review.

Personally, I think it's really important to have system tests for this feature to make sure it works as expected. Some of the system tests can be written now (for brokers 0.8.2.x and 0.9.0.x), but we probably can only write the ones for 0.10.0.0 once trunk has bumped the version of request types used by the producer and consumer. Testing at the `NetworkClient` level is not really enough as we want to make sure the errors are propagated all the way to the user.
Review by @ewencp.

Yes. For JoinWindows it is `left.ts - before <= right.ts <= left.ts + after` (with "left" and "right" being a record from the left/right stream, respectively. For TimeWindows, it is `ts \in [start, star+size)`.
@guozhangwang Rebased.

@junrao Thanks a lot for the patient and careful review. I am on vacation in China from Jun 22 to Jul 11. The network becomes a little flaky. Could you help kick off a system test? I will see if I can go to our newly opened Shanghai office and use the VPN there to run the performance test on our test cluster. Thanks again.

This is an alternative implementation to https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1535 
There are fewer code changes in the consumer/fetcher, at the expense of a slightly more complex listener
@ewencp @guozhangwang thoughts on this approach?

@ijuma I am planning on adding system tests for it. However, I want to get some feedback on overall approach. Though I had outlined the same approach as a response to Jay's question on KIP-35 discuss list, it wasn't discussed in great details. Gwen too had some questions on overall approach, to which I have posted answers earlier. I have discussed the approach with @hachikuji though, but review from a committer who can eventually help to commit this will help. Meanwhile, I can work on system tests.

The failed test, `KStreamRepartitionJoinTest.shouldCorrectlyRepartitionOnJoinOperations` seems unrelated. It passes locally. Did not find a JIRA for marking this as an unstable test, however I could not reproduce test failure locally, let me know if it still warrants a unstable test JIRA. @ijuma would you be able to review this one?

@guozhangwang     Mackbook 12 inch 2015 early edition, 1.3GHz dual-core Intel Core M processor (Turbo Boost up to 2.9GHz) with 4MB shared L3 cache.
8GB of 1600MHz LPDDR3 onboard memory
I think that it has to do with attaching yourkit profiler.
Without the profiler I get the following 

producer
Producer Performance [MB/sec write]: 22.247686586525987
consumer 
Consumer Performance [MB/sec read]: 56.39283169836138
simple stream performance source->process
Streams Performance [MB/sec read]: 40.33237957119899
simple stream performance source->sink
Streams Performance [MB/sec read+write]: 18.71113212350438

Process finished with exit code 0

Yes, a JIRA for the unstable test would be appreciated. With regards to this change, I share some of Grant's concerns given the lack of existing MirrorMaker tests and the fact that the benefit seems a bit esoteric. Also, no test is included in this PR.

Any thoughts @becketqin?

Filed KAFKA-3896 to track the unstable test.

The original issue, which I agree was not really causing any obvious
problem, led to uncovering of offset commits happening faster than
specified `offset.commit.interval.ms`. Though that is again not an obvious
issue, but certainly an unexpected behavior. Review from @becketqin will be
helpful. Also, on the tests side, I am trying to think how can this be
tested. Would appreciate any suggestion on that.

Would have been better if the JIRA spelled out an actual problem. I'm OK leaving it as it is or using the offset commit interval for the poll timeout (which seems intuitive and low-risk). At the very least, it would be nice to have the comments which clarify why the poll interval must be small since it is not obvious just looking over the code.

@SinghAsDev Offset commits don't happen faster than specified as far as I can see. The potential issue is if you set the `offset.commit.interval.ms` to be _lower_ than 1 second (the hardcoded poll timeout), then the offset commit may not happen within the time you specify if poll ends up waiting for 1 second because no messages have been received (for example). Of course, this only matters if there are uncommitted messages since the previous poll, which again needs a specific sequence of events (a poll that takes less time than the `offset.commit.interval.ms` so that the messages returned are not immediately committed).

Am I missing something?
@hachikuji, I agree that we should include the comment no matter what.
@ijuma my bad, you are right. If you folks think using `offset.commit.interval.ms` is very risky then I will be fine with just adding an explanation on why the hard coded value.

@SinghAsDev Yes, it makes sense to get agreement on the overall approach before spending more time on this. I am a bit undecided on this one. It seems a bit wasteful to make an additional request to check the versions to simply fail if they don't match. The broker should really be returning an error when an unsupported request arrives.

What would be really cool is making the Java client support multiple broker versions. But that would require a discussion in the mailing list and it would be a bigger change.
@bbejeck I think `Thread.sleep` is fine here. Just make sure that we will `Thread.sleep(Math.min(100L, time-remaining))` in case the remained time is less than the hard-coded backoff value.
LGTM. Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0 (marked fix version is 0.10.0.1)
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.0.
Merged to both trunk and 0.10.0.
I spoke with @junrao and he agreed that removing it seemed best.
LGTM

@Ishiihara Since this patch was repurposed for KAFKA-3824, can you make sure it addresses the issue raised there? Maybe it would be OK just to emphasize that autocommit provides at-least-once delivery. Also I had one comment above which may have been missed.
@ijuma This makes sense to me - when we log this, everything is still working... we just warn that once the ticket expires, we can no longer renew it again.

Can you please update the PR title and description? Note that the PR description becomes the comment in the merged commit, so it should focus on the change only.

The change LGTM, but let's wait for the outcome of the mailing list discussion you started @theduderog.

> It seems a bit wasteful to make an additional request to check the versions to simply fail if they don't match. The broker should really be returning an error when an unsupported request arrives.

This was discussed and agreed upon as part of KIP-35. Below is an excerpt.

> Java clients will use this API to assert that current API versions are all supported by the brokers it is talking to, and raise an exception if they are not. Java clients check will test the new API.

I think it has value to know that clients are not compatible with brokers it is trying to talk to, rather than getting connection dropped or similar not so sure response.

> What would be really cool is making the Java client support multiple broker versions. But that would require a discussion in the mailing list and it would be a bigger change.

This was proposed in KIP-35 and was shot down. We should definitely give it a try again, but as you said this will be a larger and lengthier discussion. Getting everyone on same page when it comes to compatibility definition, has not been so easy :).

@gwenshap That's reasonable. However, we log errors in a number of cases where we fail to refresh (and exit the thread) even though everything is still working (after all, we try to renew a while before expiry as a general rule). So, what makes those other cases different? I guess in this case the expiry could be well into the future, which is indeed different.

LGTM then.
retest this please
LGTM.

@wushujames I haven't looked too deeply, but this seems like a promising approach to me. How do you plan to hook into the different places where metrics are exposed? The consumer metrics are currently spread across several classes (e.g. ConsumerCoordinator, NetworkClient, Fetcher, etc). I could imagine creating a `ConsumerMetrics` class which maybe links to all of these in some way. Then we could include the main method in that class just like we do with `ConsumerConfig`.
We also need a note in upgrade.html.
@dguy Any idea why it would fail? Is it a timing issue?
It must be timing on the slow build boxes. I've not seen it fail locally and i've ran it repeatedly as part of the build and individually

Yes, I am aware of KIP-35 discussions and outcome. All those discussions happened with 0.10.0 in mind, which has now been released and this part of the KIP didn't make it into that release. Part of the motivation for this part was to ensure that ApiVersions request worked properly. That's a weaker argument now since we have already released it and we relied on other clients to test it for us.

I agree that there is value in knowing that clients are not compatible with brokers (which was the main motivation). However, we are only doing it this way because we don't have a way to return a generic error on any request, which is a bit of a shame.

On the topic of supporting multiple broker versions, yes, KIP-35 wasn't the right place for that. However, now that KIP-35 is in, it could be considered again. It's weird that the Java clients don't support this when third-party clients do. If we did this, there would be less of a need to backport client fixes to older versions (which people often can't upgrade because of the brokers). Anyway, it would be interesting to think if the approach we are doing now could be extended in that direction.

It just occurred to me that we are not handling the SASL case correctly. For that case, we need to send the `ApiVersionsRequest` before the `SaslHandshakeRequest` (see `SaslClientAuthenticator`). Right?

Finally, I don't mean to block this from going in, I was just sharing my thoughts on the subject. Since there is value and it was approved as part of KIP-35, as long as we can ensure that we don't break existing behaviour and that the new functionality works correctly, it seems like it can go in.

Jenkins failures are unrelated, I ran the tests locally and they passed.

Merged to 0.9.0.

@dguy mentioned offline that the code paths the leftJoin is executing are covered by other tests, and hence why he suggested removing the test. I am not too familiar with the code, so I'll let @guozhangwang review it.

My take is that it's important to understand how a slow build box could cause the incorrect result and if there's a way to make the test more robust, that would probably be better (my opinion is not as well-informed @dguy's and hence why I'll defer to whatever @guozhangwang thinks).
@ijuma I have added unit tests.
@ijuma I've add a note in the upgrade doc if you can take a look.
Review by @enothereska @dguy @mjsax @miguno
LGTM
Updated upgrade doc based on @ijuma's feedback.

LGTM. Thanks @bbejeck ! It'll be great to update the unit tests using the helper functions in TestUtils in `kafka-clients`, and remove the corresponding duplicate helper functions in `kafka-core`'s `TestUtils`. Could you file a JIRA?
Merged to trunk.
Keep in mind that a number of `kafka-core`'s `TestUtils` functions use lambdas so they can't really be replaced.
Also, seems like I was late adding my comments. They can be addressed in a follow-up PR once there is agreement.
LGTM
LGTM
Thanks @mjsax , merged to trunk and 0.10.0.

@dguy which test case do you think covers this last verification already?

BTW I have also seen that no records or fewer-than-expected messages were produced in the integration tests, even after 30 / 60 seconds: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3882. So I think parallel running integration stream tests may some time stall completely.
@bbejeck you can just create a follow-up PR without new JIRA ticket, for example: https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1513
@bbejeck Also, feel free to continue the discussion in this PR so that we reach consensus before you make the changes. Most of my comments had questions attached to them. :)

> Keep in mind that a number of kafka-core's TestUtils functions use lambdas so they can't really be replaced.

Ack.

@guozhangwang the repartition logic is covered by all of the other verifications in that test. The leftJoin is covered by JoinIntegrationTest.
I've ran the build repeatedly on my maxed (100%) laptop and I have yet to get any failures.
ping @ijuma @guozhangwang
@guozhangwang PTAL.

Not sure why this test is failing, it runs fine locally. I have tried several runs in a row and still no failures.  The only change is to use the OS default temp directory vs hard coding the temp directory to be "/tmp".  I'll continue to look into this.  Should the values for the STATE_DIR_CONFIG be reverted?
Added in modifications to integration/internals unit tests
@bbejeck, that failure is unrelated to this PR, see https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1549
It is a bit puzzling why this seems to happen relatively often in Jenkins, another instance here: https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-trunk-git-pr-jdk7/4400/

My main comment is about improving the (java)docs of this PR.
IMHO we must more clearly explain _why_ e.g. state store names must be provided by the user.  "Why do I need to provide this param at all? Doesn't make sense to me!"  Also, once a state store is named, we should also explain how you can actually make use of the stores (if you have the name).

Right now we only tell the user "you must provide this new string param, and for joins you must even provide two strings".  But we don't explain the value and why of all this plus we don't explain the "how" of re-using the exposed state stores.

@guozhangwang @ijuma - i've changed the JoinWindow to 1 day  (from 1 minute) and this looks like it has fixed the issue. I checked the previous failures on Jenkins and this test was taking around 1.5 to over 3 minutes - so a 1 minute JoinWindow for this test was too small. 
I've ran it without fail on jenkins https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-trunk-debug/  (the one failure wasn't a test failure).
Still failing on KStreams test:  `org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.KStreamRepartitionJoinTest > shouldCorrectlyRepartitionOnJoinOperations`

@wushujames Yeah, that sounds good. I was thinking it might be possible to reference the different metrics instances (e.g. SelectorMetrics) without relocating them. One of the challenges I'm realizing is that some of the metrics are initialized according to application-specific behavior (such as a new connection being initialized). It seems like we'll need to pull those metric templates to the top level somehow. Maybe it's as simple as creating a template map which is keyed by the metric name, but I'm not sure.
This seems not to be a valid PR -- if you want to report a bug, please subscribe to Kafka mailing list (see https://kafka.apache.org/contact.html). @guozhangwang @miguno @enothereska @dguy

Updated PR and Issue title to just add explanation on why hard coded value is used. We can take up the issue of using `offset.commit.interval.ms` as poll timeout when and if we see any issue related with it. @ijuma mind giving it another pass.

@ijuma I agree with all you said. However, one of the issues I keep running into is that the longer a KIP or a PR remains open the more times its intent changes. Could we agree on adhering to what we decided on KIP-35 scope and let this go in, sure I will work on fixing any issues with it. This will make sure that we will have at least this basic check in Java clients in the next release. I have plans on using KIP-35's support to make rolling upgrade easier and along that we can initiate thoughts around adding support for multiple brokers. I am sure that it is going to take some time, however we definitely will have more insight as third party clients would have some working examples for us to point at. If you agree, then I can start looking into SASL issues you pointed out and adding tests. Will wait for your response.
LGTM overall. After @ijuma 's comments are addressed I think it is good for merging.

Thanks for the investigation @dguy , the reasoning is reasonable to me.

LGTM and merged to trunk.

Thanks @HenryCaiHaiying , one general comment:

I'm not sure if we should return the whole `StreamsConfig` object from the `ProcessorContext`, since this is a top-level class and hence may better be not exposed to developers working as lower-levels. Instead, how about adding a slightly different API:

```
Map<String, Object> appConfigs();  /* return all the key-value pairs in properties */
Map<String, Object> appConfigsWithPrefix(String);  /* return all the key-value pairs started with the prefix in properties, this can be implemented via AbstractConfig.originalsWithPrefix */
```

Other than this, this patch LGTM.
Merged in apache:kafka trunk to my changes into PR so that it's a proper merge with trunk.

This is a good find @kawamuray . As for its fix, instead of creating a callback object each time and potentially creating lots of short-lived objects (some may move to old-gen if it last too long?), I think we'd better fix 

https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/producer/internals/RecordBatch.java#L107-L109

by returning the RecordMetadata still if `exception != null` but without the timestamp and offset values. cc @ijuma as it touches the producer internals.

@guozhangwang that seems consistent with https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1015/files#diff-0436bd6994adccd181bfe6d02555cbc2R781
It's probably a good idea to include an upgrade note as some people may assume that if `metadata` is not `null`, then the `exception` is `null`.

@stathmarxis I assume you are reporting a problem, not contributing a PR to ASF Kafka, right? The reported issue in your case is likely to be this one: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3559 and we are actively working on this.
Thanks for the pointer @ijuma .

SRE should be able to control the receive buffer size of sockets that are used to receive request from clients, for the same reason set receive buffer size for all other sockets in the server and client. However, we currently only set the send buffer size of this socket.
Thanks for the PR. I think you meant to say `ReceiveBufferSize` in the title.
@ijuma Yeah you are right. Fixed now.

@lindong28, we call `serverChannel.socket().setReceiveBufferSize(recvBufferSize)` in `openServerSocket`. The documentation says:

``` java
     * Sets a default proposed value for the SO_RCVBUF option for sockets
     * accepted from this <tt>ServerSocket</tt>. The value actually set
     * in the accepted socket must be determined by calling
     * {@link Socket#getReceiveBufferSize()} after the socket
     * is returned by {@link #accept()}.
```

Have you verified that your change has an impact?

@hachikuji I've spent some time on this and it seems to involve restructuring of the code to some extent (assuming I haven't over-complicated things). So I'm wondering whether we should keep the changes simpler and do this work and unit tests in separate work items.

@vahidhashemian Either way works for me. I don't think there's any particular hurry to get this patch in since it will probably go in 0.10.1, so if restructuring the code seems like a good idea, I'm probably slightly in favor of doing it here so we don't forget about it later. That said, I know it can be painful to fill in some of these testing gaps (they're gaps because testing wasn't easy!), so if @junrao is OK with it, then doing it separately seems fine to me.

@jcustenborder Actually, how did you end up hitting this issue? The JsonConverter seems like it properly checks for null values and optional before it calls any of the conversion code. I haven't checked AvroConverter or the other direction, but I'm curious because it seems easier to have a single check before trying to call all this code (and having only 2 of these) than to have all logical types have to handle this themselves. Thoughts?

@ijuma  - latest round of comments addressed.

@guozhangwang  - thanks for the review.
Updated the PR according to the comments, please take a look.
PR is updated regarding to the comments, please take a look.
@ijuma Thanks for the quick review. I have verified that my change has an impact.
@lindong28 Thanks. Can we have a test then? It seems like the javadoc I quoted is not correct.
LGTM, alternatively you can use FileChannel.open as @ijuma suggests.

If you like it as is so far, we could also consider more unit testing for aggregation triggering the suppression of nulls and also possibly bringing in a non-Lambda of UserRegion example from Confluent to apache (here) assuming it would work as expected.
cc @granders
LGTM
